Chapter 4, Section 5: Discrimination of Dependent Origination, Part 5. Thus far, the world of sentient beings has been discussed. The world of the vessel will now be discussed.
Verse:
The arrangement of the world of the vessel: the wind wheel is at the very bottom,
Its extent is immeasurable, and its thickness is 16 koá¹­is.
Above it, the water wheel is 110 million and 20 thousand [yojanas] deep,
The lower 8 koá¹­is are water, the rest solidifies to form gold;
This water and gold wheel is 12 koá¹­is across,
3,450 [yojanas], and its circumference is three times that.
Discussion:
This world system of a billion four-continent worlds is thus arranged, destroyed, and formed together.
This is because sentient beings naturally cultivate and attain various meditative absorptions, and after their lives end below, they are reborn in the second meditative absorption and above.

The world of the vessel is destroyed by the three calamities. After a long time, based on the empty space below, due to the power of the increased karma of sentient beings, a slight wind arises, turning and increasing later, twisting and forming a wheel. Its substance is firm and dense.
Suppose there is a great NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, who with a vajra wheel fiercely strikes it with all his might, the vajra may be shattered, but the wind wheel is undamaged.
Thus, the wind wheel is vast and countless, sixteen koá¹­Ä«s of yojanas thick.
Moreover, due to the power of the increased karma of sentient beings, great clouds and rain arise, pouring down on the wind wheel, the drops like chariot axles, accumulating water to form a wheel.
Thus, the water wheel, in its unfrozen state, is eleven koá¹­Ä«s and twenty thousand yojanas deep, and as vast as the wind wheel.
Some say it is small, held by the karma of sentient beings, preventing it from dispersing, like food and drink that have not yet been digested, which will never flow and fall into the stomach.
Other masters say:
It is held by the wind, preventing it from flowing sideways, like a basket holding grain.

The power of sentient beingsâ€™ karma causes a special wind to arise that strikes the water of the wheel of water and turns it into gold, just as when fresh milk is left to stand, the cream forms on the surface. Therefore the wheel of water decreases to a thickness of only 800,000.
The rest turns into gold, which is 3,200,000 yojanas thick.

The two wheels are separate and consist of 100 koá¹­is. The breadth of each of the two wheels is the same, namely, 1,234,500,000 yojanas. The circumference is three times that, namely, 36,036,500 yojanas.
The three wheels have been discussed. We shall now discuss the mountains.
A verse says:
Mount Sumeru is in the center, next is Yugandhara,ğŸ”½Mount Äªá¹£Ädhara, Khadiraka,
Mount SudarÅ›ana, AÅ›vakará¹‡a,
Mount Vinataka, and Mount Nimindhara.
Outside the continents, etc., is the Iron Ring Mountain.ğŸ”½A verse says:
The first seven are made of gold, and Mount Sumeru is made of four precious substances.
They enter the water for 80,000 yojanas, and Mount Sumeru emerges the same amount.
The other eight decrease by half, and their widths are equal to their heights.
The treatise says:
Above the golden wheel there are nine great mountains. Mount Sumeru is located in the center, and the other eight surround Mount Sumeru.
Among the eight mountains, the first seven are called inner. Outside the seventh mountain there are great continents and so forth.
Outside of this there is another Iron Ring Mountain, which surrounds the four continents like a wheel.

The seven mountains beginning with Mahendra are only made of gold. Mount Sumeru is made of four precious substances, namely gold, silver, lapis lazuli, and crystal, on its four sides in sequence, north, east, south, and west.
The color of the sky is manifested according to the majestic virtue of the precious substances. Therefore the sky of JambudvÄ«pa is similar in color to lapis lazuli.
From what do such precious substances and so forth arise?
From the power of the increase of the karma of sentient beings,

again a great cloud arises, raining on top of the golden wheel, the drops like chariot axles, passing through a long time, the accumulated water rushing and surging, its depth exceeding eighty thousand [yojanas]. A violent wind churns and strikes, producing treasures and other things.

In this way, when the transformation of gold, treasures, and other things is completed, again due to the power of karma, a separate wind is aroused, distinguishing treasures and other things, gathering them and forming them into mountains and continents, dividing the sweet and salty water to form the inner and outer oceans.
How can water of one kind produce treasures and other things of different kinds?

The rain water can serve as the repository for the seeds of different treasures and other things, and again it is churned by various powerful violent winds, producing various treasures and other things. Therefore there is no fault.
In this way, the nine mountains rest on the golden wheel, and the amount they are submerged in the water is all the same, eighty thousand yojanas. Mount Sumeru emerges from the water in the same way.
In this way, it is said that from the bottom of the golden wheel up to the peak of Mount Sumeru, there are a total of one hundred and sixty thousand yojanas.

The remaining eight mountains, from the inner to the outer, are half the height of the water they emerge from. That is, the first mountain, Yugandhara, emerges from the water for 40,000 yojanas, up to the last mountain, CakravÄá¸a, which emerges from the water for 312.5 yojanas.
The width of each of these nine mountains is the same as the height of the water they emerge from.
Having explained the nine mountains, we will now explain the oceans.
The verse states:
Between the mountains are eight oceans, the first seven are called inner,
The first is 80,000 yojanas wide, each side is three times that,
The remaining six are half the width of the previous, the eighth is called outer,
240,000 yojanas, with 3,200 yojanas remaining.
The treatise states:
From Sumeru as the first to CakravÄá¸a as the last, there are eight oceans in between. The first seven are called inner. All seven are filled with water possessing the eight qualities:

The first is sweet, the second is cold, the third is soft, the fourth is light, the fifth is pure, the sixth is odorless, the seventh does not harm the throat when drunk, and the eighth does not injure the stomach when drunk.
Thus, the first of the seven seas is 80,000 yojanas wide, and its inner circumference around Mount Dvirada is three times as much on each of its four sides, totaling 240,000 yojanas.
The other six seas are half the size of the previous one, with the second sea being 40,000 yojanas wide, and so on up to the seventh sea being 1,250 yojanas wide.
The reason why the circumferences are not mentioned is because it would be too much, and because it can be known from the previous explanation.
The eighth sea is filled with salty water, and its width is 32,412.5 yojanas, with 12.5 yojanas remaining. The remaining yojanas are indicated by the word and.
Having explained the eight seas, we will now explain the differences in shape and size of the various continents.
In verse it is said:
In the middle, the characteristics of the great continents are: JambudvÄ«pa in the south is like a chariot,
Each of the three sides is two thousand, and the south side is three and a half.
The eastern continent Videha is shaped like a half-moon,
with three sides like JambudvÄ«pa, and the east side is three hundred and fifty.
The western continent GodÄnÄ«ya is shaped like a full moon,
with a diameter of two thousand five hundred, and a circumference three times that.

and there are eight intermediate continents, two on each side of the four continents.
The treatise says:
In the outer ocean, there are four great continents, facing Mount Sumeru in the four directions.
JambudvÄ«pa in the south is broad in the north and narrow in the south, with three sides of equal measure, shaped like a cart.
The south side is only three yojanas and a half wide, and each of the three sides is two thousand yojanas.

Only in this continent is there a diamond seat, reaching to the top of the earth and supported by the diamond wheel below. All bodhisattvas in their final incarnation who are about to attain supreme perfect enlightenment all sit on this seat and give rise to the diamond-like concentration. This concentration is supported by nothing else, and no other place has the firm power to support it.
In the Eastern Continent of Superior Body, the east is narrow and the west is wide, and the three sides are equal in size, shaped like a half-moon.
The east is three hundred and fifty yojanas, and the three sides are each two thousand yojanas.
Because the eastern continent is wide on the eastern side and the southern continent has a southern boundary, the east is like a half-moon, and the south is like a cart.
The western continent of Cattle is shaped like a full moon, with a diameter of two thousand five hundred yojanas and a circumference of seven thousand five hundred yojanas and a half.
The northern continent of Kuru is shaped like a square seat, with equal measurements on all four sides, each side two thousand yojanas long, and a circumference of eight thousand yojanas.
The faces of the people in each continent are shaped accordingly.
There are also eight intermediate continents, which are the dependents of these four continents.
The two intermediate continents adjacent to JambudvÄ«pa are CÄmara and Avara-cÄmara.ğŸ”½The two intermediate continents adjacent to PÅ«rvavideha are Deha and Videha.
The two intermediate continents adjacent to GodÄnÄ«ya are ÅšÄá¹­ha and Uttaramantrina.
The two intermediate continents adjacent to Kuru are Kurava and Kaurava.
All of these continents are inhabited by humans, born there due to the dominant power of inferior karma. Therefore, the humans who live there have small bodies.
Other masters say:
The continent of CÄmara is inhabited by rÄká¹£asas, while the others are all inhabited by humans.
Having discussed the continents,
in which direction and how large is the Anavatapta Pond?
In verse it is said:
To the north of this are the nine black mountains, within the Snow, Fragrant, and Intoxicated Mountains,
The Anavatapta Lake is fifty yojanas long and wide.
The treatise says:

In this JambudvÄ«pa, starting from central India and going north, there are three layers of black mountains each, with the Great Snow Mountain to the north of the black mountains. North of the Great Snow Mountain is the Fragrant Intoxicating Mountain. To the north of the snow mountains and south of the fragrant mountains is the great pool called Anavatapta, which gives rise to the four great rivers, flowing from the four sides to the four great oceans. The first is the Ganges River, the second is the Sindhu River, the third is the SÄ«tÄ River, and the fourth is the Vaká¹£u River.
The Anavatapta Lake is fifty yojanas long and wide on each side, filled with water of the eight virtues. It is difficult for those who do not have spiritual powers to reach it.
Beside this pool is the JambÅ« Forest, with trees that are tall and large, and their fruits are sweet and delicious. Because of this forest, it is called JambudvÄ«pa, or it is named after this fruit.
In which place are the hells established?
How many are there and what are their dimensions?
A verse says:
Below this, at a distance of twenty thousand yojanas, is AvÄ«ci, deep and wide like the others,
The upper seven hells are each sixteen yojanas larger.
Namely, the burning embers, excrement, razor-edge, and flaming river increase,
Each occupying the four sides, with the other eight cold hells.
The treatise says:

Below this JambudvÄ«pa, at a distance of twenty thousand yojanas, is the great AvÄ«ci Hell, deep and wide like the others, namely each twenty thousand yojanas. Therefore its bottom is forty thousand yojanas from here.
Why is there an AvÄ«ci Hell only under this continent?
Because extremely grave evil karma is produced only in this continent, because calamities such as warfare exist only here, and because the people of this continent have the sharpest faculties.
Because there is no pleasure to interrupt, it is called AvÄ«ci.
Although there is no pleasure as retribution in the other hells, there is no great fault, because there is pleasure as outflow.
Some say that the name AvÄ«ci is established because there is no gap, and although there are few sentient beings, their bodies are large.

Some say that in this hell, suffering is experienced without interruption. That is, each sentient being is nailed with a hundred nails, and at the six sense bases, they constantly experience intense suffering. They dwell on a ground of red-hot iron surrounded by iron walls, with raging flames constantly burning without a moment's respite. The body is tormented by heat, and the pain is unbearable.

Although there are four gates that appear to be open when viewed from a distance, when they run to escape, they find the gates closed. Their wishes are not fulfilled, and they are devastated and wounded.
They throw their own bodies as fuel into the raging fire, burning their limbs, flesh, and bones to a crisp. Sustained by evil karma, they do not die.
The remaining seven hells are stacked above AvÄ«ci.
What are the seven?

First, the Extremely Hot Hell; second, the Flaming Hot Hell; third, the Great Screaming Hell; fourth, the Screaming Hell; fifth, the Hell of Compressing and Combining; sixth, the Black Rope Hell; seventh, the Hell of Revival.
Some say these seven are beside AvÄ«ci.
The limbs and joints of one's own body and the bodies of others, both inside and out, all emit fierce flames that burn each other, and because the heat is extreme, it is called extreme heat.

The fire follows the body, blazing all around, and the suffering of heat is difficult to bear, so it is called blazing heat.ğŸ”½Suffering is intense, and one emits a great, cruel sound, lamenting and crying out in resentment, so it is called great crying.
Suffering is intense, and one cries out in various ways, lamenting and crying out in resentment, so it is called crying out.
Many instruments of suffering come together to oppress the body, and they destroy each other in groups, so it is called mass destruction.
First, black ropes are used to measure the limbs and body, and then they are cut with a saw, so it is called black ropes.
Suffering oppresses the body, and one often faints as if dead, but then recovers as before, so it is called reviving.

It means that although the sentient beings there are subjected to various kinds of chopping, stabbing, grinding, and pounding, when they are briefly struck by a cool breeze, they recover as before, and because they are the same as those who live before, it is called reviving.

The eight hells of increased suffering each have sixteen additional hells, with four additional hells outside each of the four gates. They are not all called by different names, but are simply designated by their fixed number.
Therefore the Blessed One spoke this verse:
These eight hells I say are very difficult to cross,
With a ground of red-hot iron, surrounded by iron walls,
With four gates on the four sides, closed with iron doors,
Skillfully arranged in size, each with sixteen additional hells,
Many hundreds of yojanas in size, filled with evildoers,
Everywhere the flames interpenetrate, with fierce fires always blazing.

Among these sixteen, the suffering experienced is more intense than in the original hells, so they are called increased.ğŸ”½Or, in these hells one experiences various kinds of suffering, with many types of suffering instruments, so they are called increased.
Or, after experiencing suffering in the hells, one again encounters this suffering, so they are called increased.
Some say that sentient beings, having emerged from hell, again encounter suffering, and therefore it is said to be increased.
Each gate has four increases. What are their names?
Hot embers, excrement, sharp blades, and boiling water are the four increases of each gate, and the names are all similar.

The increase of hot embers means that in this increase, hot embers fill up to the knees, their quantity is vast and broad, many yojanas. When sentient beings enter this, as soon as they lower their feet, their skin, flesh, and blood all burn, rot, and fall off, but when they lift their feet, they return to normal as before.

The increase of corpses and excrement means that in this increase, corpses and excrement fill it, and the stench is deep and submerges people, and it is broader than the quantity of the previous increase of hot embers. In it, there are many nyagrodha worms, their tips are sharp like needles, their bodies are white and their heads are black. When sentient beings enter there, they are all drilled by these worms, their skin is pierced, their bones are broken, and they are gnawed and eaten by the marrow.
The increase of sharp blades means that in this increase, there are three kinds:

The road of sword edges is a road laid out with sword edges pointing upward. When sentient beings walk on it, as soon as they put down their feet, their skin, flesh, and blood are cut and crushed, falling to the ground. When they lift their feet, the skin, flesh, and blood grow back as before.

The forest of sword leaves is a forest with leaves made entirely of sharp sword blades. When sentient beings go under it, the wind blows the leaves down, cutting and stabbing their limbs and body, with bones and flesh falling off. There are black dogs that knock them down, bite their heads, gnaw their feet, tear at their necks, rip open their fat, tear open their bellies, pull out their hearts, and drag them around to eat and devour them.

The forest of iron thorns is a forest with iron trees towering over a hundred people. There are sharp iron thorns sixteen inches long. When sentient beings are forced up and down the trees, the sharp thorns stab them up and down. There are iron-beaked birds that probe and peck at the sentient beings' eyes, heart, and liver, competing to eat them.
Although the three kinds of roads of sword edges, etc. are different, they are the same as iron rods, so they are included in one increase.

As for the river of hot lye, it is a river whose quantity is deep and wide, filled with hot salty water. Sentient beings drown in it, either floating or sinking, going upstream or downstream, horizontally or vertically, being steamed and boiled, with their bones and skin melting away.

It is like a large cauldron filled with lye, with hemp and rice placed inside, fiercely burning below. The hemp and so forth revolve up and down inside, with their entire bodies melting away. Sentient beings are also like this.
Even if they want to escape, on both banks there are prison guards holding knives and spears, warding them off and preventing them from returning, with no way to get out.

There are also prison guards who spread out a large iron net, filtering out sentient beings and placing them on the bank, pouring molten copper into their mouths and making them swallow hot iron balls, experiencing all kinds of suffering, then throwing them back into the river.
This river is like a moat, and the previous three are like gardens, surrounding and adorning the great hells.ğŸ”½The eight hot hells have already been explained.
There are also eight cold hells.
What are the eight?
The first is Arbuda, the second is Nirarbuda, the third is Aá¹­aá¹­a, the fourth is Hahava, the fifth is Huhuva, the sixth is Utpala, the seventh is Padma, and the eighth is MahÄpadma.
In these hells, sentient beings are afflicted by severe cold, and are named according to the sounds and changes of their bodies, such as the second, third, and third [hells] in order.

These cold hells are outside the surrounding mountains of the four continents, in the extreme darkness. In them, there are always fierce cold winds blowing up and down, swirling horizontally and vertically.

Sentient beings wander here, gathering together and relying on each other. The severe cold cuts into their bodies, causing their skin to blister and crack. Their bodies tremble and stiffen, each making different sounds. The wounds open and split, resembling the three flower patterns. This suffering is mostly brought about by slandering the sages and saints.

Some say that these hells are next to the hot hells, because the continent of JambudvÄ«pa is pointed above and broad below, shaped like a grain bin, and therefore can accommodate them. Therefore, the great ocean gradually becomes deeper and narrower.

The sixteen great hells are all produced by the dominant karma of sentient beings. The other solitary hells are either produced by the individual karma of many, two, or one, or they are near rivers, mountains, wildernesses, or underground, in space, or elsewhere.
In the great AvÄ«ci, the great hot, and the flaming hot hells, there are no jail guards to guard them.
In the three hells of great wailing, wailing, and gathering, there are few jail guards, and the messengers of King Yama sometimes come and go to inspect them.
The rest are all guarded by jail guards.
Because sentient beings and insentient beings of different species guard and punish the sentient beings with offenses, the fire does not burn them.
The sentient jail guards are because their bodies separately receive different primary elements, or because they are blocked by the power of karma.
The bodies of all hell beings are all upright, and they originally speak the holy language.
It is heard that they say in the holy language:
You did not observe the faults of desire among humans, nor did you respectfully serve Brahmins and ascetics, and therefore you now experience this severe suffering.
Having heard this, they understood and felt ashamed and remorseful, but later they became unclear due to the torment of suffering.
The arrangement of the various hells is like this.

The abodes of animals are in the water, on land, and in the sky. The species have boundless differences in appearance and form. Their bodies are mostly horizontal with few upright ones. They originally lived in the ocean but later spread to the five destinies. Initially, they spoke the same as the sages, but gradually their speech became distorted.
The ghosts originally lived in the realm of King Yama, and from there they spread to other places.

Under the southern edge of this JambudvÄ«pa, it is more than five hundred yojanas deep. There is the capital of King Yama, which is also that size in length and width.ğŸ”½There are three kinds of ghosts, namely those with no wealth, little wealth, and much wealth.ğŸ”½Those with no wealth are of three kinds, namely torch-mouth, needle-mouth, and foul-smelling mouth.
Those with little wealth are also of three kinds, namely needle-hair, foul-smelling hair, and goiter.
Those with much wealth are also of three kinds: those who desire offerings, those who abandon, and those with great power.
The extensive explanation of these nine is like the Correct Principles.
However, among ghosts, those without majestic virtue exist only in the three continents, excluding the northern continent.
If there are those with majestic virtue, they also exist in the heavens.
To the west of JambudvÄ«pa, there are five hundred islands, of which two are inhabited only by ghosts.
Each island has two hundred and fifty cities. Ghosts with majestic virtue live in one island and one city, while ghosts without majestic virtue live in another island and city.
Most ghosts walk upright, and at the beginning of the eon they all spoke the language of the sages. Later, in different places, there were various deviations.
As for the meaning of the size of the places where the sun and moon reside, the verse says:
The sun and moon are half of Mount Sumeru, fifty-one and fifty,
Midnight, sunset, noon, and sunrise are the same in the four continents,
In the second month of the rainy season, the nights gradually increase by nine,
The fourth month of winter is also like this, with the night decreasing and the day increasing in reverse.
When the sun travels the southern and northern paths,
the moon is near and its own shadow covers it, so the moon's disk appears incomplete.
The treatise says:
On what do the sun, moon, and stars depend to abide?
They depend on the wind to abide.
It is said that the power of the karma of all sentient beings jointly produces wind that rises, circling in the sky around Mount Sumeru, carrying the sun and so forth, preventing them from falling.
How many yojanas is their abode from here?
At the peak of the Double-peaked Mountain, it is halfway up Mount Sumeru.
What is the diameter of the sun and so forth in yojanas?
The sun is fifty-one, the moon is only fifty, and the smallest star is half a kroÅ›a, the largest is sixteen yojanas.
Do the four continents have separate suns and moons?
No, the four continents share the same sun and moon.
Do they perform their functions in the four places simultaneously?ğŸ”½No.
How is it then?

Midnight, sunset, noon, and sunrise are the same in the four continents, because Kuru, JambudvÄ«pa, GodÄnÄ«ya, and Videha are situated facing each other across Mount Sumeru.ğŸ”½If it is midnight in Kuru, it is noon in JambudvÄ«pa, sunset in Videha, and sunrise in GodÄnÄ«ya.
If it is noon in GodÄnÄ«ya, it is midnight in Videha, sunset in JambudvÄ«pa, and sunrise in Kuru.
The brief meaning is that in whatever continent it is noon or midnight, in the other two continents it is sunset or sunrise as appropriate, and in the third continent it is midnight or noon.

Therefore, when it is noon or midnight in Videha and GodÄnÄ«ya respectively, at that time there is light in all four continents, but the function of light is in the southeast continents, in the northwest continents there is only the function of light, and in the north and south continents both functions are seen.

That is, JambudvÄ«pa sees the sun rise and the moon set, and sees the moon rise and the sun set. Kuru sees the sun and moon rise and set at the same time. PÅ«rvavideha only sees the sun rise and only sees the moon set. GoÅ›á¹›á¹…ga sees the sun and moon rise and set at the same time.
The rest should be considered in the same way.
Why is there decrease and increase of day and night?
Because the sun's path over the continents is different.

From the ninth day of the second month of the rainy season, the nights gradually increase. From the ninth day of the second month of the cold season, the nights gradually decrease. The times of increasing and decreasing days are the opposite of this.
When the nights gradually increase, the days gradually decrease. When the nights gradually decrease, the days immediately increase.
When days and nights increase, by how much do they increase in one day and night?
They increase by one lava. When days and nights decrease, it is the same.
When the sun moves south of the continent, and when it moves north of the continent, then the nights and days increase and decrease respectively.
Why is it that at the end of the dark half and the beginning of the bright half, the moon's disk is seen to be incomplete?
In the worldly teachings, it is explained like this:
When the lunar palace moves close to the sun, the sun's light invades and illuminates the moon, causing the shadow on the other side to cover the lunar palace, making it appear incomplete.
This must be the principle, because at that time the entire bright lunar palace is also seen.
Therefore, when the sun sets and the moon appears, it is seen as a full moon because it is very far away.
What sentient beings inhabit the palaces of the sun and so on?
They are inhabited by the gods belonging to the Heaven of the Four Kings.
Do these gods only inhabit these places?
If they are gods who inhabit space, they only inhabit the palaces of the sun and so on.
If they are gods who inhabit the ground, they inhabit Mount Sumeru.
How many terraces are there on the mountain?
What are their sizes?
Which gods inhabit which terraces?
A verse says:
There are four terraces on Mount Sumeru, each ten thousand yojanas apart.
They extend out sixteen, eight, four, and two thousand yojanas,
The Heaven of Firm Hands, the Heaven of Holding Garlands, and the Heaven of Constant Arrogance are the great kings' retinue.

The treatise says:

Mount Sumeru has four levels. From the water level to the end of the first level, the distance is ten thousand yojanas. In the same way, from the third level to the end of the fourth level, it is also ten thousand yojanas.

These four levels extend out from Mount Sumeru and surround it to the halfway point. The first level extends out sixteen thousand yojanas. The second, third, and fourth levels extend out eight thousand, four thousand, and two thousand yojanas, respectively.

The gods residing on the first level are called Firm Hands. Those in the second are called Holding Garlands. Those in the third are called Constant Arrogance. The Four Heavenly Kings and their retinue each reside in one direction on the fourth level.
The three heavens of Firm Hands and so forth are all included in the retinue of the Four Heavenly Kings.
The seven golden mountains such as Mount Bhundika also have villages and towns ruled by the four heavenly kings. These are called the four heavenly kings who dwell on the ground.
Among the desire heavens, this heaven is the most extensive.
Where do the thirty-three heavens dwell?
Verse:

In the four corners there are four peaks, where VajrapÄá¹‡i resides.

Half of its height is a golden city, with a soft ground adorned with various decorations.

Discussion:
The Thirty-three Celestials live on the peak of Meru, which is twenty thousand yojanas on each side, and if we count the circumference, it comes to eighty thousand.
Other masters say:
Each side is eighty thousand, and the distance from the peak to the four sides is the same.
At the four corners of the peak there is each a peak, five hundred yojanas high and wide.
There are yaká¹£a spirits called VajrapÄá¹‡i who live there, guarding the celestials.
On the peak there is a palace called SudarÅ›ana, two thousand five hundred on each side, and ten thousand yojanas in circumference.

The golden city is one and a half yojanas high, and the ground is level and also made of true gold, adorned with a hundred and one kinds of mixed jewels. The touch of the ground is soft like cotton. When one steps on it, it rises and falls with the height of the foot. This is the great city ruled by Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra.

The city has a thousand gates, which are magnificently decorated and imposing. At each gate there are five hundred blue-robed Yaksas, who are brave, upright, and majestic, each one yojana in size, all of them fully armed to guard the city gates.

Within the city there is the Supreme Palace, which is adorned with various wonderful treasures, surpassing the palaces of other gods, hence the name supreme. It faces in four directions, each side being two hundred and fifty yojanas, and the entire circumference is one thousand yojanas.
These are the delightful things within the city.
Outside the city on all four sides there are four gardens, which are places where the gods gather to play together.
The first is the Chariot Garden, where various chariots appear according to the gods' blessings.
The second is the Rough Garden, where armor, weapons, and other necessities appear according to need when the gods wish to go to war.
The third is the Mixed Forest Garden, where the gods enter and enjoy themselves together, giving rise to supreme joy.
The fourth is the Joyful Forest Garden, where extremely wonderful objects of desire of various kinds gather, and one never tires of contemplating them.
In this way, the four gardens are all square, each measuring one thousand yojanas on each side.
In the middle of each is a wish-fulfilling pond, each side fifty yojanas long, filled with water possessing the eight excellent qualities.

On the four sides outside the four gardens are four excellent lands, each twenty yojanas away from the gardens. Each side of the lands measures two hundred yojanas. They are the places where the heavenly beings engage in supreme play, and the gods compete in victory and enjoy themselves there.

Outside the city, to the northeast, is the Tree of Life, which is the supreme place where the thirty-three celestials experience the pleasures of desire. Its roots extend deep and wide for fifty yojanas, and its trunk rises up with branches spreading out, one hundred yojanas high and wide.
When it sprouts leaves and flowers, a wonderful fragrance pervades the air. With the wind, the fragrance fills one hundred yojanas; against the wind, it still pervades fifty yojanas.

Outside the city, in the southwest corner, there is the Great Good Dharma Hall, where the thirty-three celestials gather from time to time to discuss and decide matters of the asuras and others, according to the Dharma and not according to the Dharma.

What is the difference between birth from desire and birth from pleasure?
In verse it is said:
Those who wish to be born in the three realms of desire, those who wish to be born in the three realms of form, and those who wish to be born in the nine realms of form.
The treatise says:

As for the three realms of desire, there are sentient beings who enjoy receiving the present subtle desired objects. They have mastery over these present desired objects, referring to the entire human realm and the lower four heavens.

There are sentient beings who enjoy receiving the subtle desired objects created by themselves. They have mastery over the subtle desired objects created by themselves, referring only to the fifth heaven of transforming and enjoying created objects.

There are sentient beings who enjoy receiving the subtle desired objects created by others. They have mastery over the subtle desired objects created by others, referring to the sixth heaven of freely partaking of the creations of others.
Based on what are these three realms of desire established?

Based on receiving the present desired objects as they are born, based on receiving the desired objects created by oneself as one wishes, and based on receiving the desired objects created by others as one wishes.
Moreover, it is based on the lower, middle, and upper objects that are received.

The first is based on the enjoyment of present objects of desire that are sinful and troublesome; the second is based on the enjoyment of objects of desire that are transformed by oneself, which are sinless but troublesome; the third is based on the enjoyment of objects of desire that are transformed by others, which are sinless and not troublesome.

The three kinds of happy births are the three kinds of happiness experienced in the nine places of birth in the three meditations, because the retribution they experience is only happy and not painful. Therefore they are called happy births.
Based on what are these three kinds of happy births established?

They are established based on the many who abide in the happiness of separation from birth, the happiness of concentration, and the happiness of separation from happiness, or based on the three kinds of calamities that reach them, or based on the predominance of investigation, joy, and happiness, or based on the difference and non-difference of body and thought.

The distance from any heaven to the ocean below is the same as the distance from that heaven to the one above it.

In this way, the distance is very great, many yojanas.

When the higher realms come down, it is not the transformed body below, because the lower eyes cannot see it, as it is not their domain.
